title: From Low-level Sensors to High-level Intelligence: Activity Recognition Links the Knowledge Food Chain

author: Qiang Yang, The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology

segmentation: Good morning, welcome to the first session.
It's my great pleasure, an honor to introduce our first speaker today, Chung Young.
Chung, I've known for many years now.
In fact, I wrote a paper with Chung before I actually met him in person many, many years ago, and it was always a great pleasure to work with him.

He is currently a professor of computer science at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology and a little known fact about Chung is the fact that he got his bachelors in science, not in computer science.
Like many of us, but in astrophysics at Peking University.
He then went on to get a Masters degree 2 Masters degree, one in astrophysics and one in computer science at the University of Maryland, College Park.
And then he got his PhD at University Maryland as well.

OK, so actually there's a machine learning methodology known as transfer learning.
The idea is to make use of as much of the old knowledge as possible and apply that knowledge for the benefit of improving the learning performance in a new scenario.
OK, so in.
This work we apply transfer learning on three scenarios.
One is transfer across different devices.
The second is transferred across time and the third is transfer across spaces.

Particularly in this work, we use latent multitask learning.
